justification: “The Cambridge gambling task [CGT] measures impulsivity by gauging decision-makers’ willingness to wait in order to make larger or smaller bets…”
“…delay discounting tasks [DDT] such as the Monetary Choice Questionnaire measure impulsivity as a function of binary choices between two alternatives…”
“They also completed personality measures including the Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (Patton et al., 1995)…”, identifying it as a self-report instrument for impulsivity.
The article lists “the UPPS Impulsive Behavior Scale (Whiteside & Lynam, 2001)” among personality measures administered to assess facets of impulsivity.
Participants “completed … the Buss-Warren Aggression Questionnaires (Buss & Warren, 2000)”, signalling this scale as the measure for aggression.
The methods note administration of “the Levenson self-report psychopathy scale (Levenson et al., 1995)”, indicating it operationalises psychopathy.
Assessment included “structured interviews and the screening version of the Psychopathy Checklist (Hart et al., 1995; Hare, 2003)”, using this checklist to measure psychopathic traits.
An IQ assessment and “the Fagerström test for nicotine dependence (Heatherton et al., 1991)” were administered, explicitly linking the construct to this test.
The sample completed “the Wender Utah rating scale for ADHD (Ward, 1993)”, identifying this instrument as the ADHD measure.
Participants underwent “an IQ assessment using Raven progressive matrices (Raven, 2000)”, specifying this test as the IQ measure.
The protocol included “the Sensation-Seeking Scale (Zuckerman et al., 1964)”, indicating this scale quantifies sensation-seeking.
Later analysis links CGT β to “inhibition failures in the Stop Signal paradigm”, and the task itself is listed among “other behavioral measures”, showing it operationalises response inhibition.
The Go/No-go task is enumerated among behavioral measures and the discussion notes its indices of “response inhibition”, tying the construct to this task.

The “Balloon Analogue Risk Task (Lejuez et al., 2002, 2003)” is included as one of the behavioral tasks “used later on to assess which dimensions of impulsivity are predicted by which model parameters,” marking it as a risk-taking measure.
